body: Well it would have to have some default value which i guess would be well known?
We could randomly generate one. Saves whatever tool that needs it from having to do so and restart.

I don't think a default value would make sense: it would have the same effect as disabling it.
I was thinking that having a generated api key by default would be better for security on machines with multiple users.
But then the tool needs to scrape config.xml
Which tool? Shouldn't a tool that needs to access syncthing be given the syncthing api key?

Well not every user is technical or capable enough. Currently I believe syncthing-gtk and maybe even syncthing-android sets up a api key on first boot which they are aware off and need. Having it setup on first boot means they will have to scrape files to get it which is not cool.

Also having an API key does not solve the problem as you can still make requests using basic auth.

Syncthing-GTK generates API key itself when 1st run wizard is used or just refuses to work if user tries to use it with already configured Syncthing, authentication and no API key. Having API key always generated certainly would be be improvement.

For the record, when running syncthing from a wrapper like syncthing-gtk, using something like `syncthing -gui-address=127.0.0.1:$someRandomPort -gui-apikey=$randomSessionKey` sidesteps the entire issue.
(Not that I see a problem with auto generating a key on first launch, like all the other stuff we auto generate, if that's what we want)

@AudriusButkevicius I manually write a random API key to the config on first start, and then read it back out whenever the app is started.

But I should really use the command line flag.

@calmh Yes, but syncthing-gtk can as well connect to already running instance (started by rc.script for example), so setting environment variables and command line arguments is not always possible.

Just for my info, is there any downside of having some API key always generated?
Well how do you figure out the key if the some random key is in place? And if it's not using the default directory for the config?

@AudriusButkevicius ST-GTK is reading Syncthing configuration from `$XDG_CONFIG_HOME/syncthing/config.xml` initialy, along with API key. If that file is not available, it's assumed that Syncthing was never used and 1st run wizard is displayed. Non-default configuration location will probably work only if XDG_CONFIG_HOME var is set...
